n-2nacfna-1ne-ë-VAspectcontinuative prefix for verbs with initial a. These are verbs stressed on the first syllable occurring in the first person so that they already have the first person prefix a attached to the root. These combinations are homophonous with the potential mode prefix.Seyök nahodek honġ ḳatimeng balu arig naha.I was coming and stealing your cucumbers and my brother and I were eating them.Alu nado Joġ.We are/were living at Jog.
=N=Potential mode for Class 3 verbs. The actual or realis forms of Class 3 verbs begin with one of the voiced fricatives (gg, h, v), the lateral (l), the vibrant (r), the semi-vowels (y,w) or the affricate (s). The potentials are formed by nasalisation which fuses with the initial consonant of the actual form. The resulting initial consonant of the verb is either a prenasalised voiced stop at the same point of articulation or a nasal. Initial s and y are somewhat irregular in that N+s becomes ng, and N+y becomes n, j, or ng depending on the verb. The fricative h only occurs in first person forms of gg initial verbs and the result of the fusion is the prenasalised stop ġ. The semivowel w only occurs as the second person form of gg initial verb and the result of the fusion is the prensalised, labialised stop gw.
na-1nacfn-2VModeThe potential mode prefix for verbs of class 1 which are stressed on the first syllable. Class 1 verbs which are not stressed on the first syllable show no change for potential mode.Su kwam bo nabë ġena huk ngwë!Don't consider going to another garden!Nabë Ratuk tetolin nah menadiiḳ og gwebë ngwii saga na megök.If Ratuk rolls back and becomes unconscious, then lay that grass skirt over him.

nabon-nabonna.ˈᵐbon na.ˈᵐbonNcAn ornamental plant used in tattooing. A name or mark was outlined on the skin with lampblack, and the skin nder the mark was pierced with needles. Leaves of this plant were then heated and the moisture squeezed out and rubbed into the skin. This left a permanent mark, and in the days before World War II these marks were made, usually on the forehead of those working in the goldmines at Bulolo, to indicate that the person concerned could speak Tok Pisin.Maluh los avëh dësarömin nabon-nabon los ram ahë in dësis ḳanaḳ raḳ nemaj.Men and women mix nabon-nabon with soot from a lamp to mark their hands.Labiatae, Plectranthus sp.1.5Plant6.5.1Building
nabööna.ˈᵐbɔːNmagic; love magic. This includes various items such as ginger, or the leaves, bark or other parts of various plants were used by young men to attract girls. These things, known by the generic term naböö were placed in the G-string or headdress of the young man when he was dancing, or used in other ways such as speaking the girl's name to the ginger in the form of a spell. Naböö was also used for a counter spell. For example, it was put on the road so that people would have to step across it. This would render any naböö of their own innocuous and so they wouldn't be able to seduce the girls of the first group.Naböö ahë kul.The potency of the naböö has been nullified.Ruh avëh in ḳo naböö.He enticed a girl because he had naböö.4.9.4.1Sorcery4.3.3Love

nën2nenN(inal)To follow one's own inclination. To do as one pleases without reference to or caring for anyone else. To go according to one's own inclination. It usually indicates a breakdown in relationships and communication. It is often used in mourning songs when referring to the departure of a loved one, leaving the mourner behind here on earth.Ġevuu nëm sa.You left me because you didn't like me.Ġeköpeḳ om ya nën ḳeva!You were so slow in going so naturally he went without you (according to his own desires)!Ya om maam ġemedo nëm.He went so don't worry about it, you just stay here.Sa nanëġ.I myself will go (never mind about you).8.3.5.3.3Unique3.4.1.1.8Pleased with3.4.1.2Happy

nudengˈnuⁿd.əŋcfahë nudengcomp. ofahëNaura, memory, spirit, influence. The 'spirit' of a departed guest; the memory or influence left behind when one stays somewhere for a short time and then departs; sickness caused by someone's departure if they have a bad spirit. This influence can then affect one's yam gardens etc too. For example, if someone can't sleep the night after someone's departure because of fleas, then insects will eat their yams. Water was put in a coconut shell by the door so the spirit of the departed guest would not bother those staying behind.Sa hevonġ nudeng vu ham genaya.I have left my aura behind and am leaving.Nudeng vu hil in mehö sënë lo gujeng ya.The aura of the person who stayed here and left is still with us.Hur mahen nepelë yi in neggëp loḳ nudeng.The child tossed and turned because he was sleeping in someone's aura (the place where they had slept and left their influence or aura behind).Su gwevonġ nudeng vu he.Don't leave your aura with us (so we can't do anything).Hil nahëp loḳ yi nudeng.We stay at home today and tomorrow, and don't go to the garden, because he's just left (and his spirit or aura is still with us).

nyëɲeN(inal)1chin.Sa kër nyëġ gwëbeng.I shaved this morning.2beginning, first.Yö verup ya nedo ya nyë.He arrived first (and the others (presumably) would come later).8.4.6.1.3End9.5Case3edge, corner.Ya nare ya begganġ nyë.He went and stood by the corner of the house.Nyë keyëh raḳ ġelönġ.The edge broke on a stone.7.3.6.3Limit6.5.4.2Boundary4wound, scar, mark. When used in this way, it usually occurs with the instrument which caused the wound, e.g. ḳele nyë 'spear wound', beġö nyë 'club wound, taram nyë 'gunshot wound'. It represents the place where the weapon hit, and may be used to refer to the scar once the wound has healed. It can also be used to refer to the mark left by other things, e.g. mun nyë could refer to the piece of sweetpotato etc left after a rat as eaten part. The teeth marks would be apparent and called mun nyë.Degelu Jaroom atov wirek om sën dënër yi bë Ḳele-nyë.They speared Jaroom before so they called him "spear-scar".3.5.7.1Writenyë nyëësɲeːt͡ʃNVariety of tree. The bark of this tree is used for tying. It is also beaten into a kind of cloth and is one of the main sources of bark for making stringbags. The leaves may be eaten.Nyëës yiḳ ḳele mahen ti sën devasu vahek raḳ navi.The nyëës is a small tree whose bark is used for making stringbags.Urticaceae, Broussonetia papyfera L'Herit.1.5.1Tree
nyëġɲeᵑɢN1place, location.Nyëġ vanġ rot.The weather is beautiful.Deya nyëġ adingnë.They went to a distant place.Nekesik nyëġ.He is cutting the grass.7.5.9Put4.5.6Status4.6.7.2City7.3.4.3Put down2sun. This is the term for 'sun' used in the village of Mapos and environs, but is not used in Humek and other parts of the valley where the word for sun is hes. The fact that the word for 'sun' has fallen together with the word for 'place' in Mapos may have originally had something to do with the fact that people do not use the names of their in-laws, and Hes is a proper name in the Mapos area.Nyëġ pangalin.The sun shone brightly.1.1.1.1Moon1.1.1.3Planet1.1.1.2Star1.1.1Sunnyëġ adingComp.ɲeᵑɢ a.ˈⁿdiŋ1distant place.Sir vahi deyam vu nyëġ ading.Some of them have come from distant places.Gwëbeng sa nado nyëġ ading gesa ḳevu ġaġek sënë yök vu ham.Now I am living far away and I have written this message to you.8.2.6.2Near7.5.9Put4.5.6Status8.5.1.5Touching, contact4.6.7.2City7.3.4.3Put down8.5.1.2Beside8.2.6.1Far8.5.1.5.1Next to2for a long time.Sa ḳööḳ nado nyëġ ading.I sat there quite still for a long time.He sero nyëġ ading ading, rëk ma.We searched for it for a very long time, but we didn't find it.8.2.2.3Short, not tall8.2.2.1Short, not long8.4.3Indefinite time8.2.2Long3.3Wantnyëġ ġebusComp.ɲeᵑɢ ᵑɢə.ˈᵐbut͡ʃcfbuminhaunted place, spirit place, tabu place.These are usually dark or dangerous places characterised by cliffs, turbulent waters, or are in some other way forbidding.
